newsitem.title: THAILAND: Idled Thai textile plants in talks with utility.
newsitem.headline: Idled Thai textile plants in talks with utility.

text.p: Officials from a Thai electric company and two textile plants have met in a bid to settle unpaid, multi-million dollar power bills which have idled the factories, workers at the plants said on Thursday.

Workers at Thai American Textile Co Ltd told Reuters that officials of the state-owned Provincial Electricity Authority (PEA) had met executives of their company as well as with Thai Melon Textile Co Ltd to try and find a way to settle unpaid electricity bills amounting 202 million baht ($7.77 million).
"I think the talks would bear some fruitful results which would allow the plants to resume operation," said one worker.
The PEA cut electricity supplies at both plants on May 1 after their owner, Chutipat Photiratnanangkul, was unable to pay the four-month-old bills.
Both plants produce textiles and are located in Bangkok's neighbouring province of Pathum Thani.
The PEA said it was the first time it had had payment problems with either of the companies, which have been operating for about three decades.
About 3,000 employees out of some 12,000 are still staying in houses built on the factories' compounds. The two plants are using generators to produce electricity for the workers.
